title: Quiz 4: HIV/AIDS & Cancer Management
description: Comprehensive quiz on the phases, symptoms, and management of HIV/AIDS and Cancer in HBC.

questions.question: Match the Phase of HIV/AIDS to its description:

pairs.right: Entry/Window period (HIV present but not detectable)

questions.explanation: Phase 1 is the window period; Phase 2 is asymptomatic but test-positive; Phase 3 is the clinical disease.

questions.question: Which of the following are MAJOR signs of AIDS in adults? (Select all that apply)

richContent.content: Recall: Diagnosis usually requires 2 major + 1 minor sign.

questions.explanation: Major signs: Weight loss >10%, Diarrhoea >1mo, Fever >1mo. Thrush and dermatitis are minor signs.
questions.hint: Think of the most systemic/severe symptoms.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of HIV counselling and testing in order:

items.text: The test decision or pre-test counselling

questions.question: To diagnose AIDS in a child, the presence of at least ___BLANK___ major and ___BLANK___ minor signs is required.
questions.explanation: Children require 2 major and 2 minor signs. Adults require 2 major and 1 minor.
questions.hint: For children, the numbers are equal.

questions.question: Which term describes tumours that are invasive, metastasising, and rapid growing?
questions.explanation: Malignant tumours are invasive and spread (metastasise). Benign tumours are encapsulated and slow-growing.

questions.question: Match the level of cancer prevention with its example:
questions.explanation: Primary = Lifestyle change to prevent occurrence. Secondary = Screening/Early detection. Tertiary = Treatment.

questions.question: What is 'Metastasis' in cancer?

options.text: When the tumour grows and spreads beyond its primary site
The surgical removal of a tumour

questions.explanation: Metastasis refers to the spread of cancer cells from the primary site to other parts of the body.

questions.question: Which vitamin supplementation is given every six months to children aged 1-5 years for health promotion?
questions.explanation: Vitamin A is given to children; 100,000 IU for infants, 200,000 IU for children 1-5 years every six months.
questions.hint: The vitamin essential for eyes and immunity.

questions.question: Patients with radiation implants should be cared for in the same room as children and pregnant mothers to avoid isolation.
questions.explanation: Pregnant mothers and children under 18 should NOT visit or stay with patients with radiation implants due to radiation risk.

questions.question: Which of the following are common side effects of Chemotherapy that HBC providers should monitor? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Chemotherapy drugs are toxic and cause nausea, hair loss, and marrow depression. They typically cause fatigue, not increased energy.
questions.hint: Think of the harsh effects of cancer drugs.
